selected_quotes: Thinking big gives top predators the competitive edge more here
Top predators constrain mesopredator distributions by @NewsomeTM et al. @deakinresearch @DeakinCI…
Top predators constrain mesopredator distributions #365papers #ecology Congrats
Top predators constrain mesopredator distributions: The Enemy Constraint Hypothesis examples from three continents
To Mitigate Problem Predators, Give Wolves More Space Study: @DeakinCIE @Sy…

citation.abstract: Top predators can suppress mesopredators by killing them, competing for resources and instilling fear, but it is unclear how suppression of mesopredators varies with the distribution and abundance of top predators at large spatial scales and among different ecological contexts. We suggest that suppression of mesopredators will be strongest where top predators occur at high densities over large areas. These conditions are more likely to occur in the core than on the margins of top predator ranges. We propose the Enemy Constraint Hypothesis, which predicts weakened top-down effects on mesopredators towards the edge of top predators' ranges. Using bounty data from North America, Europe and Australia we show that the effects of top predators on mesopredators increase from the margin towards the core of their ranges, as predicted. Continuing global contraction of top predator ranges could promote further release of mesopredator populations, altering ecosystem structure and contributing to biodiversity loss.
citation.title: Top predators constrain mesopredator distributions

news.title: Wolves need room to roam, study says
news.summary: ***File image*** (Photo: KING) Wolves need more room to roam in order to keep other predators – like coyotes – in check.

blogs.title: Wolves need space to roam to control expanding coyote populations

Wolves and other top predators need large ranges to be able to control smaller predators whose populations have expanded to the detriment of a balanced ecosystem.

blogs.title: Wolves Need More Room to Roam
blogs.summary:
Ecologists say wolves should be allowed to roam beyond remote wilderness areas—and that by scaring off smaller predators like coyotes and jackals, wolves might do a good service, too. Emily...
-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com
